canvases.label: The Approach of Krishna. Page from a Rasamanjari

metadata.label: Title
metadata.value: The Approach of Krishna. Page from a Rasamanjari

metadata.label: Provenance
metadata.value: Stella Kramrisch, Edward L. Whittemore Fund

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On verso in Sanskrit:  "Friend give up your waywardness of mind. O dear friend do not torture me with your shyness. For a moment, the lord Kama forgive me, be steadfast in your gaze. May the handsome Krishna wearing peacock feathers on his head, putting lotus in his ears and holding the flute on his hand reveal himself to me now."

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value: On recto in Takri : "Seeing the lover face to face."

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value:
Archer, W. G. Indian Paintings from the Punjab Hills; a Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. London, New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1973.

Dwivedi, Vinod P. “A Rasamanjari Painting from Basohli.” The Bulletin of the Cleveland Museum of Art, vol. 56, no. 7, 1969, pp. 262–268.

Goswamy, B., Fischer, E., & Museum Rietberg. (1992). Pahari masters : Court painters of northern India (Artibus Asiae. Supplementum ; 38). Zürich, Switzerland: Artibus Asiae  : Museum Reitberg. 

Karl Khandalavala and Moti Chandra, "The Rasamanjari in Basohli Painting," Lalit Kala, nos. 3-4 (New Delhi, 1956/57), pp. 26-38.

The Cleveland Museum of Art. Handbook of the Cleveland Museum of Art/1978. Cleveland, OH: The Cleveland Museum of Art, 1978.

metadata.label: Exhibition History
metadata.value: Year in Review: 1965. The Cleveland Museum of Art (organizer) (October 27-November 14, 1965).

metadata.label: Provenance
metadata.value: Lady Rothenstein and Art Fund, Collection of William Rothenstein.

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On verso in Sanskrit : "The bracelet on her hand is making no sound; the garment on her bosom does not stir; the gaze of her pupils is fixed; and her ear-rings dance no more. There is no difference between her and a painting on canvas, unless the ripple of a thrill is awakened in her on her hearing your name."

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value: On recto in Takri: "She who lies dazed or stupefied."

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value:
Archer, W. G. Indian Paintings from the Punjab Hills; a Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. London, New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1973. Hayward Gallery, and Arts Council of Great Britain. In the Image of Man : The Indian Perception of the Universe through 2000 Years of Painting and Sculpture : [exhibition] Hayward Gallery, London, 25 March-13 June 1982. London: Weidenfeld and Nicolson, 1982.

Khanna, Balraj. Krishna: The Divine Lover, South Bank Centre, London 1997.

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On verso in Sanskrit: "The beauty of that slender girl is like a pool in which my heart and eyes have dropped. The heart, being heavy, has been completely submerged; the eyes being light, are floating all around"

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value: On recto in Takri: "The need for love"

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value:
Archer, W. G. Indian Paintings from the Punjab Hills; a Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. London, New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1973.
Khanna, Balraj. Krishna: The Divine Lover, South Bank Centre, London 1997.

canvases.label: Krisna Arrives while Radha is Dressing

metadata.label: Title
metadata.value: Krisna Arrives while Radha is Dressing

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On verso in Sanskrit: "The lotus-eyed maiden is desirous of watching your foot-path. With the appearance of new clouds, her heart goes to her throat as if to choke it. Wishing to fly away to see your moon-like face, her heart grows wings in the form of lotus-leaves. What else shall I say?"

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value: On recto in Takri : 'Annoyance because of her toilet.'

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value:
Archer, W. G. Indian Paintings from the Punjab Hills; a Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. London, New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1973.

Goswamy, B. N., Eberhard Fischer, and Museum Rietberg. Pahari Masters : Court Painters of Northern India. Artibus Asiae. Supplementum ; 38. Zürich, Switzerland: Artibus Asiae Publishers : Museum Reitberg, 1992.

metadata.label: Provenance
metadata.value: Lady Rothenstein and Art Fund, Collection of Michael Rothenstein

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On verso in Sanskrit:  "Having coaxed my lotus-faced girl to come near the couch, I eagerly prepared to loosen her bodice. Meanwhile, the clown, my friend, repeatedly crowed like a young rooster as if heralding the dawn."

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value: On recto in Takri: 'the jester friend'

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value: Archer, W. G. Indian Paintings from the Punjab Hills; a Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. London, New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1973.

metadata.label: Exhibition History
metadata.value: Rawson, Philip S., Hayward Gallery and Arts Council of Great Britain. Tantra. Hayward Gallery, London 30 September-7 November 1971. London, Arts Council of Great Britain, [1971]. p. 34, no.127.

metadata.label: Provenance
metadata.value: Lady Rothenstein and Art Fund, Collection of William Rothenstein.

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On verso in Sanskrit : "My sweet-heart, whose thighs are like plantains, eyes like lotus, locks of hair like saivala, face like the moon, speech like nectar, waist like a lotus stalk, navel like a pit, fold in the belly like a stream and hands like leaves - swells in my heart. Alas! there is still no abatement of the fever in my heart."

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value: On recto in Takri : "He whose pati (literally husband, but here by implication, mistress) is away."

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value: Archer, W. G. Indian Paintings from the Punjab Hills; a Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. London, New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1973.

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On Verso in Sanskrit: His swollen heart knows neither shame nor pity nor any fear of anger; How can such a tender bakula bud as I have been cast into his hands today?"

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On verso written in Sanskrit. "The cunning lover won the confidence of his doe-eyed nayika by decorating her braid with garlands, painting floral designs on her forehead with sandal-paste, putting armlets on her upper arms, and placing a necklace of pearls on her breast. Winning the confidence of the fawn-eyed lady he slyly loosens the knot of her skirt, with his soft hand, on the pretext of touching her belt."

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value: Randhawa, M. S., S. D. Bhambri, and Bhānudatta Miśra. Basohli Paintings of the Rasamanjari. New Delhi: Abhinav Publications, 1981.

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value: Randhawa, M. S., S. D. Bhambri, and Bhānudatta Miśra. Basohli Paintings of the Rasamanjari. New Delhi: Abhinav Publications, 1981.

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value: Archer, W. G. Indian Paintings from the Punjab Hills; a Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. London, New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1973.

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value:
On the verso in Sanskrit: "O sakhi! I am unable to say how lucky you are, for your lover adorns your body with jewel-studded ornaments. But my beloved, afraid even of a slight interruption in his gazing at me, does not decorate me."
Translation by Randhawa and Bhambri (1967)

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value:
On the top in Takri: "love proud"  
On the left border in Takri 33

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value: Archer, W. G. Indian Paintings from the Punjab Hills; a Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. London, New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1973.

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On verso in Sanskrit: Radha's eyes were filled with tears when she saw Krishna coming wearing mango blossoms in his ears and his cheeks yellow with pollen

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value: In Takri on the left  "'One who grieves at the loss of her lover" and on the top "28"

metadata.label: Publications
metadata.value:
Archer, W. G. Indian Paintings from the Punjab Hills; a Survey and History of Pahari Miniature Painting. London, New York: Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1973.
Bhānudatta Miśra, et al. Basohli Paintings of the Rasamanjari. Abhinav Publications, 1981.

metadata.label: Medium
metadata.value: Opaque watercolor, gold, and beetle-wing cases on paper

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On the reverse: 'A sakhi who knows the nayika's secret speaks to her in jest: "What was to happen has happened; what is to happen will happen; and what is happening is also happening. Any attempt on your part at concealment is therefore useless" '

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value: In Takri: 'one who has been found out or whose secret has been exposed'

metadata.label: Medium
metadata.value: Opaque watercolor, gold, and beetle-wing cases on paper

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On the Reverse in Sanskrit: 'Radha's eyes were filled with tears when she saw Krishna coming wearing mango blossoms in his ears and his cheeks yellow with pollen'

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value: In Takri : One who grieves at the loss of her lover.

metadata.label: Text
metadata.value: On the reverse in Sanskrit: 'In the winter season, her husband having told the servant to cut the ber tree, the doe-eyed nayika dropped the axe in the water'

metadata.label: Paratext
metadata.value:
Top of object in Takri :        'kria vidagdha' 
'the act of the resourceful mistress'
